title: Loopback
historical_context: This article reflects the hacker culture of the late 1990s, a time when discussions around ethics in hacking and phreaking were becoming more prominent.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: The article is a compilation of letters discussing various topics related to hacking, programming, and the hacker community's ethos, showcasing the informal and often humorous tone of Phrack.
summary: In this edition of Phrack, the staff presents a collection of letters that highlight the diverse opinions and discussions within the hacker community. The letters range from critiques of previous articles to philosophical musings on the morality of hacking and phreaking. One notable letter praises the philosophical insights found in Phrack, while another humorously critiques the quality of content in past issues. The responses from the Phrack staff maintain a light-hearted tone, often engaging with the writers in a witty manner, which reflects the camaraderie and irreverence typical of hacker culture at the time. This article serves as a snapshot of the community's thoughts and concerns, emphasizing the importance of dialogue and shared knowledge among hackers.
